awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating Eocene Shark Paleoecology and Climate Modeling to reveal Southern Ocean Circulation and Antarctic Glaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's climate has changed through time and during the Eocene Epoch (56 to 34 million years ago) there was a transition from 'greenhouse' to 'icehouse' conditions. During the Eocene, a shift to cooler temperatures at high latitudes resulted in the inception of polar glaciation. This in turn affected the environment for living organisms. This project looks to uncover the interaction between biological, oceanographic, and climate systems for the Eocene in Antarctica using chemical analysis of fossil shark teeth collected during past expeditions. The combination of paleontological and geochemical analyses will provide insight to the past ecology and ocean conditions; climate models will be applied to test the role of tectonics, greenhouse gas concentration and ocean circulation on environmental change during this time period. The study contributes to understanding the interaction of increased atmospheric carbon dioxide and ocean circulation. This project also seeks to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion within the geosciences workforce with efforts targeted to undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral, and early career faculty.

The research goal is to elucidate the processes leading from the Eocene greenhouse to Oligocene icehouse conditions. Previous explanations for this climate shift centers on Antarctica, where tectonic configurations influenced oceanic gateways, ocean circulation reduced heat transport, and/or greenhouse gas declines prompted glaciation. The team will reconstruct watermass, current, and climate fluctuations proximal to the Antarctic Peninsula using geochemical indicators (oxygen and neodymium isotope composition) from fossil shark teeth collected from Seymour Island. The approach builds on previous shark paleontological studies, incorporates geochemical analyses for environmental reconstruction (i.e., temperature gradients and ocean circulation), and tests hypotheses on Earth System dynamics using novel global climate model simulations with geochemical tracers. This project will advance global climate modeling capabilities with experiments that consider Eocene tectonic configuration within isotope-enabled climate model simulations. A comparison of geochemical results from Eocene climate simulations and empirical records of shark teeth will reveal processes and mechanisms central to the Eocene Antarctic climatic shift.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The world was much warmer in the Eocene (~55-35 mya) than today--especially in polar regions.  Sometime around the beginning of the Oligocene (~34 mya), the world cooled and Antarctica glaciated rapidly with great implications for life.  Although there was a general trend of cooling during the Eocene, this Eocene-Oligocene transition was the first big step toward the cooler world of today. We know that a reduction in CO2 was one driver of global cooling, but other mechanisms, including changes in ocean circulation--perhaps due to opening of Southern Ocean Gateways-- have been proposed.  Either way, substantial further study was necessary to understand the pattern and timing of Antarctic cooling across the Eocene and transition into the Oligocene.  

This transdisciplinary, multi-institution study brought together paleoclimate modelers, modern oceanographers, paleo-ecologists, and marine geologists to study the co-evolution of life and climate at high latitudes, through the lens of shark teeth.  The project integrated and synthesized data and methods from biology, geochemistry, ocean-atmospheric dynamics, and modeling. This combination was innovative and required regular, deep communication between the faculty, post-docs, and students across the programmatic elements.  Monthly meetings amongst all the project participants were held and the methods and research modalities of each discipline were introduced to the other teams, which generated meaningful and long lasting impacts for everyone involved.  

Within the Purdue team (led by Huber and including Phd student Adam Aleksinski and Post-doc Xiaoqing Liu) Eocene neodymium ocean circulation proxy records and paleotemperature records (either generated by other project teams, i.e. led by co-PI Sora Kim or Howie Scher or from previous publications) were compiled and georeferenced.  The neodymium and isotope enabled version of the NCAR CESM was set up and run both at NCAR and at Purdue under the mentorship of co-PI Alexandra Jahn and with great assistance from NCAR paleoclimate scientist Jiang Zhu. Long integrations of CESM were carried out that are a good match for middle Eocene conditions as revealed by comparison of modelled results with isotopic and circulation proxy records.  These simulations needed to be integrated far longer than expected because the site of deepwater formation changed after thousands of years (even after having initialized with a previous 'equilibrated' simulation). This is an interesting result by itself, suggesting either the presence of multi-equilibria or a more general necessity for >4000 year paleoclimate integrations.  Sensitivity studies at a range of CO2 and ocean gateway configurations were carried out that appear to capture the relative changes across the Eocene-Oligocene transition, although some systematic biases in models and proxy data exist, if the proxies represent annual mean conditions.  

We now have simulations that clearly delineate the relative roles of CO2 and Drake Passage depth in driving oxygen isotope and neodymium ocean circulation distributions and the necessary compilations of data to evaluate which of the proposed mechanisms best explains the available data.  In terms of intellectual merit, the main outcomes of this set of simulations are:

  1. high CO2 values are necessary to reproduce Eocene warmth and a "correct" ocean circulation; 
  2.  lowering of CO2 generates relative changes that correspond well to more Oligocene-like conditions overall; 
  3. shark teeth that we have analyzed leave wide room for interpretation and are compatible with multiple interpretations;
  4. opening of Drake Passage also clearly changes the east-west gradient of neodymium in just the way that has been previously identified in published records, which indicates that gateway opening is an important part of the neodymium tracer story;
  5.  in the model at least, the climatic implications of this are small, suggesting that CO2 is the main driver of the climate change, regardless of what is going on with Southern Ocean circulation.

More broadly, we have also learned the importance of considering the paleo-ecological and behavioral aspects of using sharks as probes of paleo-ocean circulation.  This knowledge is potentially transferable to other proxy systems in which vertical movement, migration, and potential for 'niche tracking' may be important.  We have attempted to constrain these factors as much as possible in our model-data comparison through careful consideration of these factors among the shark teeth. Further development of these concepts into a full proxy system model will likely bear fruit.

Results of this work have been presented at several international conferences, published in a series of joint publications, and associated proxy data and model output have been archived in publicly available repositories. The work of publishing the latest results is ongoing.  In terms of broader impacts, one PhD student will graduate with this as the core of his dissertation and one post-doc was trained in model-data comparison. Combined with similar outcomes among the other project partners this constitutes a lasting contribution to interdisciplinary STEM training and research capacity.  The resulting proxy compilations and model output which are or will all be publicly available through archives also constitute lasting data resources for the broader community.
